fields.headline: Rowson's riches
fields.bodyText: I hope that Steve Pound MP is not telling his homeless constituents that they cannot register to vote (Letters, August 9). As he should know, the Representation of the People Act 2000 allows a homeless person to register on the basis of a declaration of local connection. If the local authority is not promoting this facility, it is surely Mr Pound's duty to bring pressure on it to do so. Andrew Connell Cardiff • Your correspondent Richard Brunner (Letters, 6 August) is the latest to misunderstand the budget deficit. The deficit is not "like a mortgage"; that is the national debt. The deficit is the annual amount by which the debt is rising each year. Any homeowner, to use his analogy, would be well advised to avoid adding to their mortgage if they are already struggling to pay the interest. It is this growing burden of interest that is the real threat, which is why all the parties have committed to bring the deficit under control. Cllr Ian Bond Lib Dem, Redbridge • Cartoons such as Martin Rowson's Nursery Tea (7 August) are rich in detail. Have you considered printing an explanation? On Saturday I worked out five of the characters, enjoyed the ABC banner, noted the insult implied by the sole of the foot being offered, and the tablecloth – how well did I do? Susan Carr Shipston-on-Stour, Warwickshire • Now that "the blasted thing" has appeared in a crossword (4 August) we shall have to learn how to pronounce vuvuzela properly. Should it rhyme with "Methuselah", or with "Hello Sailor"? Neil Parrack Cheltenham, Gloucestershire • My neighbour at a North Carolina dinner party said she was a parter. Thinking this must be a term for a part-time worker, I probed to discover what sort of work she did. "I make parttery," she answered (Letters, 9 August). Beverley Charles Rowe London • Has anyone else noticed the inverse correlation between the amount of money spent on a wedding and the length of the marriage (Report, 7 August)? Kathleen O'Neill Hayling Island, Hampshire
